If you don't have access to a haven then there are also hospices which are not just for the terminally ill. They offer similar things to the Haven, there are also macmillan centres which offer similar things to. See what is available in your area and try out various things to suit your needs. I find that i do need a little sleep mid day from time to time. It really is a case of listening to your body and hear what it is saying to you. If you want to eat chocolate, have a little bit, if you need to sleep, have a nap. Don't worry if you lose your memory - it will come back. For me every cycle has brought something new and a predominant problem. The latest one being that my feet constantly ache. I feel like i used to feel after doing a couple of days on call when i would be working constantly, even though i'm not working at the moment and certainly not doing the amount of exercise or walking that i used to. I wonder what number 6 will bring? Katie - I use the hirudoid gel when my arm feels sore and tight as well as the exercises and massage techniques my Chemo nurse showed me. My arm hasn't got any worse over the cycles but i do have sessions where i use the gel between cycles as it does seem to start to get sore for no reason. I also use the gel the day of my treatment before i go for the infusion. The theory behind this being that the gel contains heparin which is an anticoagulant - it slows the clotting mechanism of the blood making it flow better through the veins, so when the drugs are infused the blood will carry them away from the site more quickly preventing them from sitting in the vein too long and causing further irritation. Keep strong. I'm thinking of you all
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Oldhat Morna Murphy is the nutritionist at Leeds, she is very good and has always suggested i check any advice she offers with my oncology team before i take any supplements. I agree the Haven is very pink, a colour i used to be very anti, but it's slowly growing on me. It's beaten me into submission i think. With regards to the granulocyte injection, that was partly as a result of the nadir count (for those that don't know, the nadir count is the lowest point blood cells reach during the chemo cycle). My neutrophil count went low for to long. Th injection itself has to be 24hours following treatment. The first time a district nurse came round to administer it, but i got him to show me and my husband how to do it and now my husband has that little task to do for me. To give you the full story as it will highlight a few things as to why we need to be very vigilant. On day 7 post treatment my temperature went up slightly to 38.1 but came back down an hour later to normal. I had a few sessions of feeling cold prior to this but not shivering. That night in bed i woke feeling very wet, but not hot and not cold. I didn't take my temperature as it was 3am and i really didn't fancy a trip to Leeds at that time of night if it was abnormal - silly i know. Anyway i woke the following morning feeling quiet well. I blew my nose and noticed that the mucus had a green tinge, a sign of infection. I phoned the ward due to being on chemo and the fact that colds have a tendency to go to my chest being asthmatic, and i really didn't want to risk that and the potential of things to get very nasty very quickly. Anyway i was told to report to the ward ASAP with an overnight bag just in case. They were fantastic, i had a full blood count sample taken and i was sent for an x-ray whilst waiting for the results. Which came back with a low neutrophil count, and i was on the wrong side of the slope. Anyway they admitted me and put me on IV antibiotics for a few days. During all this time i really did not feel unwell. They did daily bood counts to check my neutrophils which were still falling. The green mucus cleared quickly and they agreed to let me go home the following week but only if i promised to call them immediately regardless of the time of day or night and go straight back in should feel unwell or my temperature went up. I was happy to do this as i was in isolation and felt a bit like a caged animal after 5 days. The consultant also told me at that point that he was going to prescribe an injection to try to prevent it being so sever in the future. Which i have to say has worked. My neutrophils do still drop, the little blisters i get on my tongue around day 7 tell me that, together with my haematology knowledge, but it doesn't last anywhere near as long as it did the first cycle.  I had to attend the consultant clinic prior to my next cycle of chemo and had a few blood tests that week to check the neutrophils. It was looking like the treatment may have to be postponed as the levels were not coming back up to quickly. I attended early for my treatment as planned but had to have a blood test before hand with the possibility it may not go ahead. Thankfully all my positive thought that i put into mobilising my neutrophils paid off and they just scrapped past the magic number to allow the treatment to go ahead. I have to say I think I have a fantastic oncology team looking after me, they are really on the ball and are very good at resolving any concerns I have. But don't get me wrong if I thought they weren't looking after me they would know about it. I swapped surgeons because I didn't have confidence in the first one. Drop me line if you have any more questions or just want to chat. I'd be happy to meet for a coffee sometime to if you wish. Take care everyone. Katrina xx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi All I hope you all got spoilt rotten for mothers day. Sorry to hear your chemo was delays Oldhat, - certainly ask for a printout of your white count, they should give you it or at least let you copy it down. Don't worry about being a nuisance. It can be very empowering to understand your blood results. I always ask to see mine. On one occasion I have even managed to spot something which the nurse missed that meant i needed to have another blood test before i could have the chemo infusion. Having said that i have the advantage that it is my speciality. I hope your keyboard survived it's ginger wash. Reading all these posts makes me realise how lucky i am to have such a good team behind me. Any questions i have regarding nutrition, exercise etc they seem to be able to answer. Cherub i hope you manage to get your chemo this week. I know how frustrating it can be. You don't look forward to the chemo but just want it all over and done with. The body will sort it's white count out in due course. It may sound a bit wacky but when i was in that situation following the first cycle i used a bit of visualisation. I don't know if it worked but i had a few blood tests in the week leading up to the second treatment including one on the morning of treatment to determine if it could go ahead. Thankfully it was fine. The Breast cancer Haven taught me how to do the visualisation bit and i have used it for other things to. One thing i would suggest caution with on the food side is bananas. They are high in potassium. If your potassium is nigh on the blood results they may request another test before the chemo is given. This is because a high potassium level may cause heart problems.  Bev - You will love the Look good feel better session. Good on you doing the race for life to. I did that last year and really enjoyed it. So much that i have signed up for the Jane Tomlinson York 10k at the start of August. I can now look at dusting of my running shoes in ernest. I have tried to eel it up over the past few months but it has been difficult on some days. I'll check out the web site you gave to get my attire sorted too :-) Forion - you are so lucky to be able to drink coffee etc. That was the one thing that i really couldn't face. Thankfully it is now getting better and i have managed a coffee today. With no more chemo to face and just radiotherapy to go through i hopeful i can start having my morning coffee again. Katie - Tiredness is an accumulatory affect,  but i found even having a 15min nap can help that side of things. I also found my memory got really bad as did my ability to concentrate on things, so i never really planned things, i would just see how i felt when i woke up in the morning and if it was a good day i could do assorts go things, if it wasn't so good i'd just take it easy.  Thinking of you all - keep strong you're doing so well it will be over in a flash.
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Oldhat Yes i'll be in Leeds tomorrow. I'll meet you at the Haven say about 1:15ish for a drink of some sorts. So far so go without eh last cycle. I', now getting psyched up for the radiotherapy bit starting next week. I can' believe how quick it has gone. See ya tomorrow
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi All They say laughter is the best medicine and i figure it's true. I usually find the tie i'm most vulnerable to catching a cold is when i feel down. If i can laugh i can laugh it off. So keep laughing everyone hard as it may be at times. Bev - i know exactly how you feel. I felt the same after my fourth and couldn't understand it, after all i was over half way. I finally put it down to the fact that i had built myself up so much to getting half way that when i had the fourth it was kind of a let down and a reality check that although i'd made it through 3 cycles the fourth treatment was the start of the next three and in effect i had it to do all over again. It will get better from here on as you are doing so well and you are nearing the last one. It will come around quicker than you think. Chrissi - I'm don't often have colds either, normally one a year but like you when i get them they go straight to my chest and upset my asthma. Thankfully we are entering the warmer weather so there shouldn't be to many people wandering around now with colds. As you progress through your cycles you will start to relax more with regards to other peoples infections. The only advice i can offer is don't get to paranoid about it but know the signs for your own body and if you do become worried that your coming down with something let your care team know straight away regardless of the time of day or night.  One other thing that i noticed was that i get a cattarhiness following my treatments. I think this is due to the cylcophosphamide drug. It starts about a week after and last for at least a week. This time it has lasted for two weeks but i think thats due to my urge to eat chocolate (dairy food).  To help cut this down the cattarh i normally reduce my dairy intake an even cut it out completely when it has been to bad. Unfortunately the chocolate urge is winning this time. Normally I don't have due to my asthma (milk in tea and coffee and a yoghurt on the odd day). Dairy is known to be an agent that increases mucus production. On the issue of nails - mine did become more brittle and have a lovely tiger stripe pattern in white and pink. The white seems to coincide with the treatments. I have heard that eating jelly cubes can help strengthen nails. Lou - Its really lucky that you took the opportunity to have a mammogram. You must have a guardian angel looking after you. I feel so lucky to have gone to my GP when i did to. I was going to postpone it as my step son was in Afghanistan at the time, but something kept nagging away at me telling me to go as if i left things till his return things might not be so good. Odd really as i kind of knew the lump i was going with was ok. It was just a fibroadenoma, strangely enough the chemo seems to have made it shrink to almost nothing, as well as mopping up any stray cells from the lump the clinic found that i didn't know i had. I love the turkey thoughts. I'll remember that when i go to see the geneticist and have the test for the BRCA gene. I know i'll end up chuckling if the test comes back as positive as i know what will be in store.  You'd be surprised at how quickly the body can adapt. I'm now almost three weeks post last cycle and i now have a lovely fussy outline to my head where my hair is growing back. It seems i have managed to keep it this cycle. I'm tentatively starting to celebrate getting a bit of a covering ready for easter. First radiotherapy tomorrow. I have to admit to being a little anxious about it, more because of the potential effects and the fact i have to lay still for what will feel like an eternity. I'm bound to cough because of this catarrh. I have my aloe vera gel at the ready. Keep laughing every one. Kat xx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tess Have you considered trying acupuncture of reflexology. I don't have menopausal symptoms doe to tamoxifen but did have a few sessions during chemo of night sweats and found the reflexology helped. You may be able to try these out at a Haven centre or macmillan centre. Kat x
Posts.Title: Black Cohosh and hot flushes/night sweats

Posts.Content: Does anyone know how useful this really is in preventing chemotherapy induce pancytopenia (low blood cell counts). After having had prolonged neutrpenai follwing my first cycle of chemo, (my count came back into range in the nick of time for me to have my second cycle) i am now on GCSF to prevent a recurrent of the neutropenia, but i was wondering if use of Life Mel would be useful to take to prevent the reduction in other blood cells. I have found some research that suggest there maybe some use but there is not a lot or evidence to support this claim. I am also concerned that the herbs from which the bees collect the pollen are themselves not compatile with chemo as the reduce the effectiveness of the drugs. Does the process of honey making metabolise out this effect? Can anone provide more information or research they have come across?
Posts.Title: Life Mel honey

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info Tessa. It's good to know you didn't have an neutropenia. I have seen the life mel site. It does appear to prevent neutropenia but does that also relate to reducing the efficacy of the chemo. I guess i really need an Apiary specialist to understand how the bees process nectar to honey and what components remain active and which don't and thus any possible interactions with the chemo from the nectar collected form the herbs. I'm happy to give it a go at any cost as long as its not at the cost of the reducing the efficacy of the chemo on the cancer cells.
Posts.Title: Life Mel honey
